para.para: Autogenerated identifier classes and identifier objects to Themed Icons registered with .
Identifier classes should be used in attributes, XAML, or generic parameters. Where an value is expected, use the identifier object in the Id field of the identifier class.

remarks.para: This code was compile-time generated to support Themed Icons in the JetBrains application.

It has two primary goals: load the icons of this assembly to be registered with so that they were WPF-accessible and theme-sensitive; and emit early-bound accessors for referencing icons in codebehind in a compile-time-validated manner.
For performance reasons, the icons are not individually exposed with application resources. There is a custom markup extension to bind an image source in markup.
To use an icon from XAML, set an property to the markup extension, which takes an icon identifier class (nested in class) as a parameter.
Example:
remarks.code: <Image Source="{icons:ThemedIcon myres:ExtensionManagerThemedIcons+ExtensionBlank}" />
remarks.para: Sometimes you have to reference an icon from a type attriute when you're defining objects in code. Typical examples are Options pages and Tool Windows.

To avoid the use of string IDs which are not validated very well, we've emitted identifier classes to be used with typeof() expression, one per each icon. Use the attribute overload which takes a for an image, and choose your icon class from nested classes in the class.
Example:
remarks.code: [Item(Name="Sample", Icon=typeof(ExtensionManagerThemedIcons.ExtensionBlank))]
remarks.para: In codebehind, we have two distinct tasks: (a) specify some icon in the APIs and (b) render icon images onscreen.

On the APIs stage you should only manipulate icon identifier objects (of type , statically defined in in Id fields). Icon identifier classes (nested in ) should be turned into icon identifier objects as early as possible. Rendering is about getting an to assign to WPF, or to use with GDI+ / Windows Forms.

You should turn an identifier object into a rendered image as late as possible. The identifier is static and lightweight and does not depend on the current theme, while the image is themed and has to be loaded or generated/rasterized. You need an instance to get the image out of an icon identifier object. Once you got the image, you should take care to change it with theme changes — either by using a live image property, or by listening to the theme change event. See and its extensions for the related facilities.
Example:
remarks.code: // Getting IconId identifier object to use with APIs IconId iconid = ExtensionManagerThemedIcons.ExtensionBlank.Id;
// Getting IconId out of an Icon Identifier Class type IconId iconid = CompiledIconClassAttribute.TryGetCompiledIconClassId(typeof(ExtensionManagerThemedIcons.ExtensionBlank), OnError.Throw);
// Getting image for screen rendering by IconId themediconmanager.Icons[icnoid]
// Getting image for screen rendering by Icon Identifier Class themediconmanager.GetIcon<ExtensionManagerThemedIcons.ExtensionBlank>()
remarks.para: This code was generated by a pre-compile build task from a set of input files which are XAML files adhering to a certain convention, as convenient for exporting them from the Illustrator workspace, plus separate PNG files with raster icons. In the projects, these files are designated with ThemedIconsXamlV3 and ThemedIconPng build actions and do not themselves get into the output assembly. All of such files are processed, vector images for different themes of the same icon are split and combined into the single list of icons in this assembly. This list is then written into the genearted XAML file (compiled into BAML within assembly), and serves as the source for this generated code.

member.name: M:JetBrains.ActionManagement.IActionManager.ExecuteShortcut(System.Windows.Forms.Keys,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Attempts to execute the keyboard shortcut. Composite keyboard shortcuts, eg “Ctrl+K,F”, should be executed twice, once for each of the components.
member.param: The keyboard shortcut to execute. May be a part of a composite shortcut.
In a standalone configuration, has no meaning. In an embedded configurations, includes the host actions in the search list together with own actions managed by the action-manager.
member.returns: Whether the action has been executed.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Build.App.SimpleBuildRequest.Parameters
member.summary: Optional input artifacts. When running standard wrapper objectives, might specify what to run as the binary stage payload of the build.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Build.App.SimpleBuildRequest.CreateBinaryStage``1

member.typeparam: Objective for the second, binary stage.

member.summary: Creates the simple request for running a build for exactly the objective specified.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Build.App.BuildRequestEntryBinaries
member.summary: Handles binary parameters on the build request which can be overridden on the command line. There's no autodiscovery — if they're not cmdline-supplied, then they're not set.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Build.App.BuildRequestEntryBinaries.FilterOutNonBinSstg(System.Collections.Generic.List{JetBrains.Util.Storage.SimpleFileItem})
member.summary: Filters out files with build engine/script binaries by removing SSTGs which don't hold the right type of data. This would have happened later in the build, but saves passing potentially large files back and forth.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Build.App.CmdLineArtifact
member.summary: Assigns a value to a build artifact before running the build. Syntax: name=value Name is the build artifact class name, long (with namespace) or short (just local class name, if not ambiguous). Value is the string representation for the artifact value, to be coerced to artifact type with or .

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Build.App.BuildAppStartupArtifactValues
member.summary: Assigns initial startup values for build artifacts. This includes artifacts from the command line and predefined values (like ).

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Build.App.CmdLineBuildEngine
member.summary: Specifies path to the build engine binaries. See impl for comments on allowed formats.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Build.App.CmdLineBuildScriptBin
member.summary: Specifies path to the build script binaries. See impl for comments on allowed formats.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Build.App.CmdLineBuildScriptSrc
member.summary: Specifies path to the folder with *.cs build sources. If no such parameters are given on the command line, autodetects sources in well-known Platform folders. To suppress autodetection without supplying sources, pass a commandline key with an empty value.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.ActionsRevised.IActionWithFallback
member.summary: The interface allows Priority Command Target handler to control VS command overriding. 1) VS's command overridden by an an action with update requirements is executing. The interface gives an ability to process VS QueryStatus synchronously, and make a decision whether to override the VS command or to let it to be executed. 2) R#'s command that overrides VS command is executing. The interface gives an ability to fall back to VS command and not to execute R#'s action.

member.name: M:JetBrains.CommonControls.IConstrainableControl.SetLayout(JetBrains.UI.LayoutResult)
member.summary: Tells the control the details about the new layout applied to it by the controlling entity in conjunction with some . Typically, the control need not apply the given size and location because that should be done by the controlling entity. The control may change its presentation in response to the layouting details, for example, whether it's attached to the top or the bottom of the anchoring rect.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.TreeGrid.FiltersCollection
member.summary: Combines a set of tree grid filters to get the single filter usable on the tree. Exposes the property which you should bind to the tree's filter property. Add your filters to .

summary.para: The resulting filter.
Bind to the tree view.
The property value changes whenever the set of filters changes, thus notifying the tree of the need to recalculate the filtered set.
Add/remove your filters here.
The key is just a convenience which allows to add/remove your filter object by a key.
If using lifetimes or adding forever, just create a new object.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.TreeGrid.CombiningFilterDescriptor
member.summary: Combines multuple filters. NOTE: set of filters cannot be changed because we cannot notify client (=tree) of the filter change to make it re-calculate. Use the class on your view model if you want to change the set of filters dynamically.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.TreeGrid.Revised.IFilterDescriptor.IsAccepted(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a value indicating if the given item is accepted and should be shown to user
member.param: Data item
member.returns: true - node is accepted itself and should be shown to user null - node is not accepted itself, however one of its children might be false - node is not accepted and shouldn't be shown to user, although one of its children might be
member.remarks: In case you are implementing per item filtering without knowleadge about children items you should return true if item accepted itself and null otherwise. In case you have knowledge about sub items, it would be more optimal to return true and false as final results.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.TreeGrid.Virtualization.Tests.VirtualizingCollection`1
member.summary: Specialized list implementation that provides data virtualization. The collection is divided up into pages, and pages are dynamically fetched from the IItemsProvider when required. Stale pages are removed after a configurable period of time. Intended for use with large collections on a network or disk resource that cannot be instantiated locally due to memory consumption or fetch latency.
member.remarks: The IList implmentation is not fully complete, but should be sufficient for use as read only collection data bound to a suitable ItemsControl.

member.summary: Returns a value indicating if the given item is accepted and should be shown to user
member.param: Node
User input in quick search box
member.returns: true - node is accepted itself and should be shown to user null - node is not accepted itself, however one of its children might be false - node is not accepted and shouldn't be shown to user, although one of its children might be
member.remarks: In case you are implementing per item filtering without knowleadge about children items you should return true if item accepted itself and null otherwise. In case you have knowledge about sub items, it would be more optimal to return true and false as final results.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Icons.IIconIdOwner
member.summary: An object which maintains some kind of s and can yield actual images for that type of icons.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Icons.IIconIdOwner.TryGetImage(JetBrains.UI.Icons.IconId,JetBrains.UI.Icons.IconTheme,JetBrains.UI.Icons.IThemedIconManagerPerThemeCache,JetBrains.Util.OnError)

summary.para: Gets the icon image for the given theme. Called by .
Notes to impelmentors.

You should return some image for each theme given. If you don't understand the theme, return the default image. Some themes might be composed or derived from others, use images for base themes in this case.

You don't have to do caching on what you return, even if you're running some calculations to produce the themed image. You will be called only once for the current theme (unless theme is changed to another and back), and the result (together with rasterization, if needed) will be cached by .

member.param: Identifier of the icon whose image is to be retrieved. This ID must be of type specified in . It is an error if an identifier of another type is passed here.
Theme (see for details on combining and deriving).
Allows querying for other icon images if needed to compose the icon for an ID.
How the image retrieval errors could be reported.
member.returns: The image for this theme, or fallback image for base/default theme if not available.

summary.para: Vendor name.
for JetBrains products.
MUST be present.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Updates.UpdateInfo.Description
member.summary:
A freehand description of this update.
Optional.

summary.para: The URI from which the installation package could be download. This MUST be the direct download link, not the download HTML page (see for that), as the updater might use it for fetching the installation package.
This URI need not be unique and could point to the same versionless verbatim for any most recent release builds.
Optional.
A BASE64 stream with a serialized to be displayed as an icon for this update.
Optional.

The identity of this update. A link to the online information page for this particular update. MUST be unique among ALL updates — not only those currently available, but also any past and future ones.
MUST be present.
Whether this will be a free update.
If True, then the customer will not have to pay for the product.
If False, then the upgrade MIGHT require a license.
Optional.
If the pricing information is available for the product, specifies the price tag in freehand form.
should be used for free upgrades instead.
Optional.
Full name of the product installed by this update, which includes the product name plus any marketing version. This should not include the company name.
for JetBrains products.
will be used if not specified.
Optional.
Short name of the product installed by this update. This should include neither company name nor version number.
for JetBrains products.
MUST be present.
The four-component technical version of the product installed by this update.
MUST be present.

summary.para: When the updates manager is about to check for updates for this updates category, it collects the information about the local environment. The downloaded filter will be applied to this data. This event allows to replace or alter this information before it's used.
Initially, it's of the type, as gotten from the . You could change it to a serializable object of an arbitrary type.
This event should be advised on each shell startup.

When the updates manager checks for updates, it downloads the XSLT filter from , plus some optional query string parameters that identify the local environment, if needed. This event allows to replace or alter this information before it's used.
Initially, it's gotten from the , called of the result. You could change or replace the key-value pairs dictionary.
This event should be advised on each shell startup.

member.summary: Creates/activates the cat of the Shell product.

summary.para: Gets the list of update categories. Each one downloads its own list of available updates, and supports a single product.

The default category, ., is guaranteed to exist. Other categories could be added by plugins, as needed. They're persisted by the manager in the product settings, so normally you do not have to create it each time. However, it could be deleted if the settings are lost, if the updates URI is dead for some time, or if it is not activated for some time.

On startup, you should activate your category with for it to check for new updates and report them, otherwise it will consider the owner to be inactive or unloaded, hibernate, and expire after some time.
To create a new category

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Theming.LinkExtension
member.summary: Markup extension is used to provide knowledge about how to bind the value

para.para: Autogenerated identifier classes and identifier objects to Themed Icons registered with .
Identifier classes should be used in attributes, XAML, or generic parameters. Where an value is expected, use the identifier object in the Id field of the identifier class.

remarks.para: This code was compile-time generated to support Themed Icons in the JetBrains application.

It has two primary goals: load the icons of this assembly to be registered with so that they were WPF-accessible and theme-sensitive; and emit early-bound accessors for referencing icons in codebehind in a compile-time-validated manner.
For performance reasons, the icons are not individually exposed with application resources. There is a custom markup extension to bind an image source in markup.
To use an icon from XAML, set an property to the markup extension, which takes an icon identifier class (nested in class) as a parameter.
Example:
remarks.code: <Image Source="{icons:ThemedIcon myres:CommonThemedIcons+Appearance}" />
remarks.para: Sometimes you have to reference an icon from a type attriute when you're defining objects in code. Typical examples are Options pages and Tool Windows.

To avoid the use of string IDs which are not validated very well, we've emitted identifier classes to be used with typeof() expression, one per each icon. Use the attribute overload which takes a for an image, and choose your icon class from nested classes in the class.
Example:
remarks.code: [Item(Name="Sample", Icon=typeof(CommonThemedIcons.Appearance))]
remarks.para: In codebehind, we have two distinct tasks: (a) specify some icon in the APIs and (b) render icon images onscreen.

On the APIs stage you should only manipulate icon identifier objects (of type , statically defined in in Id fields). Icon identifier classes (nested in ) should be turned into icon identifier objects as early as possible. Rendering is about getting an to assign to WPF, or to use with GDI+ / Windows Forms.

You should turn an identifier object into a rendered image as late as possible. The identifier is static and lightweight and does not depend on the current theme, while the image is themed and has to be loaded or generated/rasterized. You need an instance to get the image out of an icon identifier object. Once you got the image, you should take care to change it with theme changes — either by using a live image property, or by listening to the theme change event. See and its extensions for the related facilities.
Example:
remarks.code: // Getting IconId identifier object to use with APIs IconId iconid = CommonThemedIcons.Appearance.Id;
// Getting IconId out of an Icon Identifier Class type IconId iconid = CompiledIconClassAttribute.TryGetCompiledIconClassId(typeof(CommonThemedIcons.Appearance), OnError.Throw);
// Getting image for screen rendering by IconId themediconmanager.Icons[icnoid]
// Getting image for screen rendering by Icon Identifier Class themediconmanager.GetIcon<CommonThemedIcons.Appearance>()
remarks.para: This code was generated by a pre-compile build task from a set of input files which are XAML files adhering to a certain convention, as convenient for exporting them from the Illustrator workspace, plus separate PNG files with raster icons. In the projects, these files are designated with ThemedIconsXamlV3 and ThemedIconPng build actions and do not themselves get into the output assembly. All of such files are processed, vector images for different themes of the same icon are split and combined into the single list of icons in this assembly. This list is then written into the genearted XAML file (compiled into BAML within assembly), and serves as the source for this generated code.

remarks.para: This code was compile-time generated to support Themed Icons in the JetBrains application.

It has two primary goals: load the icons of this assembly to be registered with so that they were WPF-accessible and theme-sensitive; and emit early-bound accessors for referencing icons in codebehind in a compile-time-validated manner.
For performance reasons, the icons are not individually exposed with application resources. There is a custom markup extension to bind an image source in markup.
To use an icon from XAML, set an property to the markup extension, which takes an icon identifier class (nested in class) as a parameter.
Example:
remarks.code: <Image Source="{icons:ThemedIcon myres:OptionsThemedIcons+ConnectionSettings}" />
remarks.para: Sometimes you have to reference an icon from a type attriute when you're defining objects in code. Typical examples are Options pages and Tool Windows.

To avoid the use of string IDs which are not validated very well, we've emitted identifier classes to be used with typeof() expression, one per each icon. Use the attribute overload which takes a for an image, and choose your icon class from nested classes in the class.
Example:
remarks.code: [Item(Name="Sample", Icon=typeof(OptionsThemedIcons.ConnectionSettings))]
remarks.para: In codebehind, we have two distinct tasks: (a) specify some icon in the APIs and (b) render icon images onscreen.

On the APIs stage you should only manipulate icon identifier objects (of type , statically defined in in Id fields). Icon identifier classes (nested in ) should be turned into icon identifier objects as early as possible. Rendering is about getting an to assign to WPF, or to use with GDI+ / Windows Forms.

You should turn an identifier object into a rendered image as late as possible. The identifier is static and lightweight and does not depend on the current theme, while the image is themed and has to be loaded or generated/rasterized. You need an instance to get the image out of an icon identifier object. Once you got the image, you should take care to change it with theme changes — either by using a live image property, or by listening to the theme change event. See and its extensions for the related facilities.
Example:
remarks.code: // Getting IconId identifier object to use with APIs IconId iconid = OptionsThemedIcons.ConnectionSettings.Id;
// Getting IconId out of an Icon Identifier Class type IconId iconid = CompiledIconClassAttribute.TryGetCompiledIconClassId(typeof(OptionsThemedIcons.ConnectionSettings), OnError.Throw);
// Getting image for screen rendering by IconId themediconmanager.Icons[icnoid]
// Getting image for screen rendering by Icon Identifier Class themediconmanager.GetIcon<OptionsThemedIcons.ConnectionSettings>()
remarks.para: This code was generated by a pre-compile build task from a set of input files which are XAML files adhering to a certain convention, as convenient for exporting them from the Illustrator workspace, plus separate PNG files with raster icons. In the projects, these files are designated with ThemedIconsXamlV3 and ThemedIconPng build actions and do not themselves get into the output assembly. All of such files are processed, vector images for different themes of the same icon are split and combined into the single list of icons in this assembly. This list is then written into the genearted XAML file (compiled into BAML within assembly), and serves as the source for this generated code.

para.para: Autogenerated identifier classes and identifier objects to Themed Icons registered with .
Identifier classes should be used in attributes, XAML, or generic parameters. Where an value is expected, use the identifier object in the Id field of the identifier class.

remarks.para: This code was compile-time generated to support Themed Icons in the JetBrains application.

It has two primary goals: load the icons of this assembly to be registered with so that they were WPF-accessible and theme-sensitive; and emit early-bound accessors for referencing icons in codebehind in a compile-time-validated manner.
For performance reasons, the icons are not individually exposed with application resources. There is a custom markup extension to bind an image source in markup.
To use an icon from XAML, set an property to the markup extension, which takes an icon identifier class (nested in class) as a parameter.
Example:
remarks.code: <Image Source="{icons:ThemedIcon myres:SpecialThemedIcons+InvalidIcon}" />
remarks.para: Sometimes you have to reference an icon from a type attriute when you're defining objects in code. Typical examples are Options pages and Tool Windows.

To avoid the use of string IDs which are not validated very well, we've emitted identifier classes to be used with typeof() expression, one per each icon. Use the attribute overload which takes a for an image, and choose your icon class from nested classes in the class.
Example:
remarks.code: [Item(Name="Sample", Icon=typeof(SpecialThemedIcons.InvalidIcon))]
remarks.para: In codebehind, we have two distinct tasks: (a) specify some icon in the APIs and (b) render icon images onscreen.

On the APIs stage you should only manipulate icon identifier objects (of type , statically defined in in Id fields). Icon identifier classes (nested in ) should be turned into icon identifier objects as early as possible. Rendering is about getting an to assign to WPF, or to use with GDI+ / Windows Forms.

You should turn an identifier object into a rendered image as late as possible. The identifier is static and lightweight and does not depend on the current theme, while the image is themed and has to be loaded or generated/rasterized. You need an instance to get the image out of an icon identifier object. Once you got the image, you should take care to change it with theme changes — either by using a live image property, or by listening to the theme change event. See and its extensions for the related facilities.
Example:
remarks.code: // Getting IconId identifier object to use with APIs IconId iconid = SpecialThemedIcons.InvalidIcon.Id;
// Getting IconId out of an Icon Identifier Class type IconId iconid = CompiledIconClassAttribute.TryGetCompiledIconClassId(typeof(SpecialThemedIcons.InvalidIcon), OnError.Throw);
// Getting image for screen rendering by IconId themediconmanager.Icons[icnoid]
// Getting image for screen rendering by Icon Identifier Class themediconmanager.GetIcon<SpecialThemedIcons.InvalidIcon>()
remarks.para: This code was generated by a pre-compile build task from a set of input files which are XAML files adhering to a certain convention, as convenient for exporting them from the Illustrator workspace, plus separate PNG files with raster icons. In the projects, these files are designated with ThemedIconsXamlV3 and ThemedIconPng build actions and do not themselves get into the output assembly. All of such files are processed, vector images for different themes of the same icon are split and combined into the single list of icons in this assembly. This list is then written into the genearted XAML file (compiled into BAML within assembly), and serves as the source for this generated code.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Behavior.AvalonBehaviorHelpers.AvalonBehaviorStateProperty
member.summary: Behaviors which are based on this helper use the property bag to store a DataFlow copy of the behavior state. The lifetime-driven behavior function binds to it and to the element's loaded state. The transition is as follows: when behavior property value is set, it's copied to the DataFlow property in this bag. When the property is first created, the behavior function is bound to it as follows: when both the property has a non-null value, and the element is loaded into WPF, execute with that lifetime.

summary.para: In WPF, nested focus scopes won't propagate its logical focused control state to the parent focus scope.
Attach this behavior to the root focus scope of a control graph in which nested focus scopes should propagate this state.
Why we need to propagate the state?

(1) Action system toolbars use the logically-focused element to handle commands when focus is not under the scope of the toolbar. For example, tool window toolbar command should apply to the selection in that toolwindow even when focus is in some other tool window.

(2) Restoring focus when window gets activated. Without proper propagation, if focus actually were in a nested focus scope, focus will be restored to the last-focused element in the topmost scope instead of the nested one.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.ActionSystem.ActionBar.IActionBarManagerAvalonEx.CreateActionBarForAvalonControl(JetBrains.UI.ActionSystem.ActionBar.IActionBarManager,JetBrains.DataFlow.Lifetime,System.String,System.Windows.UIElement)

summary.para: Creates an -driven toolbar to be hosted in Avalon controls with data contexts collected from Avalon controls.

member.param: Creator.
Limiting lifetime for toolbar activities.
ID of the actions group whose actions should be presented as toolbar buttons.

param.name: contextparent
param.para: Outermost control hosting the whole setup with toolbar and payload content controls.
For example, in a tool window that would be your content element. In a window, that would be the window content element. Usually the returned action bar UI element is parented by the context parent.

When keyboard focus is within the context parent, the focused element defines the data context (it's collected by bubbling from the focused element and collecting all the available data rules/constants).

When keyboard focus is not within, the logical focus context is used for gathering data context, which is basically the most recently keyboard-focused element (or, rather, which element would get focused when keyboard focus returns to the window). This allows for keeping the window-local action buttons enabled on the toolbar even when focus is not in the window itself.
To implement this, is set to True on .

member.returns: The toolbar as a UI element.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.ActionSystem.ActionBar.IActionBarManagerAvalonEx.CreateActionBarForAvalonControl_AutomaticScoping(JetBrains.UI.ActionSystem.ActionBar.IActionBarManager,JetBrains.DataFlow.Lifetime,System.String)

summary.para: Creates an -driven toolbar to be hosted in Avalon controls with data contexts collected from Avalon controls.
The UI element to collect data rules again is chosen with the : it is the focused element in the focus scope which contains the toolbar itself. Normally, it would be a window, or a toolwindow, etc.

When keyboard focus is actually within this scope, the focused element defines the data context (it's collected by bubbling from the focused element and collecting all the available data rules/constants).

When keyboard focus is not within, the logical focus context is used for gathering data context, which is basically the most recently keyboard-focused element (or, rather, which element would get focused when keyboard focus returns to the window). This allows for keeping the window-local action buttons enabled on the toolbar even when focus is not in the window itself.
If you want to limit the scope, set to True on the appropriate container.

member.param: Creator.
Limiting lifetime for toolbar activities.
ID of the actions group whose actions should be presented as toolbar buttons.
member.returns: The toolbar as a UI element.

summary.para: Creates an -driven toolbar to be hosted in Avalon controls with data contexts collected from Avalon controls.
The UI element to collect data rules again is chosen with the : it is the focused element in the focus scope which contains the toolbar itself. Normally, it would be a window, or a toolwindow, etc.

When keyboard focus is actually within this scope, the focused element defines the data context (it's collected by bubbling from the focused element and collecting all the available data rules/constants).

When keyboard focus is not within, the logical focus context is used for gathering data context, which is basically the most recently keyboard-focused element (or, rather, which element would get focused when keyboard focus returns to the window). This allows for keeping the window-local action buttons enabled on the toolbar even when focus is not in the window itself.
If you want to limit the scope, set to True on the appropriate container.

summary.para: Creates a new command corresponding to the action, and registers the command bindings on the view element to which the is applied.
Safe to call multiple times.
Sets up the view element which attaches WPF Command Bindings for Action Manager actions.
To set up the infrastructure for handling Action Manager actions as WPF Commands:
• In the viewmodel, create and expose an instance of .
• On the view element which should define the bindings (one parenting all of the command-using elements), set the behavior's attached dependency property.
• In the viewmodel, get a command for each action you need and expose to the view.
• In the view, use the command as usual (must be within the element with the behavior).
Takes part in attaching WPF Command Bindings for Action Manager actions.
Set this attached dependency property on a view element to fulfil the steps described in docs.
Registers the action with this command scope and returns a routed command which will represent the action in this scope.

member.summary: Creates a dummy theming instance for out-of-shell uses of the interface. Do not use in the real application, inject yourself the real interface from the component container instead.

summary.para: Gets a live property which determines whether the current visual studio theme operates with dark colors.
Note that this considers generic UI colors rather than text editor colors. In VS versions below 11, these might disagree.

The value depends on the actual UI colors lightness rather than the theme name in VS, which will fit with any possible theme customizations: our UI choices should be driven by actual colors rather than by any theme names.
Gets a live property which determines whether the current visual studio theme is monochrome.
Note that this considers generic UI colors rather than text editor colors. In VS versions below 11, these might disagree.

The value depends on the actual UI colors saturation rather than the theme name in VS, which will fit with any possible theme customizations: our UI choices should be driven by actual colors rather than by any theme names.
The common application theming interface.
Aggregates the , , , , interfaces.
Collects and dispatches icon images throughout the application.
Applies theming to icons to support different application styles.
Generally, you should not be getting icons from it directly. Look for strongly-typed accessors auto-generated in the assembly which loads the icons.

member.summary: Api methods for use as backend by .

member.summary: Gets the current theme selected for icons, and notifies of changes.

summary.para: Gets the icon image in vector or raster form for use with GDI+ WinForms or WPF UI.

You should be operating on objects for as long as possible, and only render an icon to the actual theme image when you have to present it. This is the main method for getting the actual theme image for an icon, either for the current theme or changing live with the theme.

remarks.para: For performance reasons, getting an icon does not validate that an icon ID is valid and an image for it exists until you actually try getting some imagery.

summary.para: Populates the resource dictionaty with applicable resources required for WPF theming.
This includes the icon manager resources and color constants.
The lifetime is required to have the live colors in resource dictionary. To get non-live, terminate the lifetime — the dictionary is not cleaned up.

member.summary: ID of the actions group whose actions should be presented as toolbar buttons.

summary.para: Outermost control hosting the whole setup with toolbar and payload content controls.
For example, in a tool window that would be your content element. In a window, that would be the window content element. Usually the returned action bar UI element is parented by the context parent.

When keyboard focus is within the context parent, the focused element defines the data context (it's collected by bubbling from the focused element and collecting all the available data rules/constants).

When keyboard focus is not within, the logical focus context is used for gathering data context, which is basically the most recently keyboard-focused element (or, rather, which element would get focused when keyboard focus returns to the window). This allows for keeping the window-local action buttons enabled on the toolbar even when focus is not in the window itself.
To implement this, is set to True on .

member.summary: Creates the panel into which the indicator view items will be put.

summary.para: If there's an Avalon status bar which belongs to some IDE which we're plugged in to (such as DevTen Beta 1), adds our indicators to that status bar.
DO NOT use this for running status bars in standalone applications, because this is a very non-straightforward way of doing things.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Avalon.Controls.AvalonStatusBarShim.TryFindDevTenBeta2StatusDockPanelInHwnd(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Means the on the bottom of the window, to which our status indicators should be added in a dock-right fashion. Usually the status bar itself sits in the same dock panel. This approach is used when we cannot deal with the status bar itself to put the items into it properly. The case in VS 10 beta 2, where the status bar control itself sits on another thread and causes a marshalling pain for us if operated directly. It's expected to be a really, but we'd fallback for cases when we find ourselves in an unexpected layout and look for just any suitable panel.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Avalon.Controls.AvalonStatusBarShim.TryFindStatusBarInHwnd(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Tries to find an Avalon status bar in the given window. The window must be fully inited by the moment.

summary.para: If there's an Avalon status bar which belongs to some IDE which we're plugged in to (such as DevTen Beta 1), adds our indicators to that status bar.
DO NOT use this for running status bars in standalone applications, because this is a very non-straightforward way of doing things.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Avalon.Controls.AvalonStatusBarShim.TryFindStatusBarInHwnd_UiThread(System.Windows.PresentationSource)
member.summary: Take 1: find all explicit status bars in the application window. Workable on VS10 up to Beta2 (non-inclusive).

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Avalon.Controls.AvalonStatusBarShim.TryFindStatusBarInHwnd_WorkerThread(System.Windows.PresentationSource)
member.summary: Take 2: in VS 10 beta 2, the status bar is hosted in another thread. There seems to be no legal way for ripping out the nested object graph. Do some hacks.
Wraps the given indicator, detaches on dispose.

member.summary: If the menu is working in the mode, specifies the mnemonic to assign to this menu item. The letter holding the mnemonic will be underlined automatically. To specify a mnemonic, either: (1) set the to contain a plaintext copy of the item , with the mnemonic char prepended by an ampersand “&”; normal ampersands should be doubled in the text, or, (2) set the to contain the single case-insensitive character of the mnemonic, whose position in the will be determined automatically; it's also legal to specify a mnemonic not present in the text. May be Null.

members.member:
Tries to execute a mnemonic. If there's exactly one item registered for this mnemonic, executes the item. If there're no items, does nothing. If there're multiple conflicting items, selects them in turn, but does not execute.
The character to be tested, either a v-key or a char representation. // TODO: switch to using the accelerator tables Whether an item was executed for this mnemonic. If we've refused to execute (returned False), tells whether it's due to the mnemonic not found (False) or duplicate mnemonic (True).

member.summary: Performs the action over the selected item, which should have enabled state for the action to succeed. Returns whether the execution was performed. If there is no selection or the item is disabled, just returns False.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.PopupMenu.Impl.JetPopupMenuDoc.ExpandSelectedItem
member.summary: If the selected item has a sub-menu associated with it, opens that sub-menu and returns the success flag. Otherwise, returns False.

member.returns: The next index, may be -1 if is or there are no [suitable] items.
member.param: Whether to go towards the end or beginning.

Whether iteration is allowed over all the items, or enabled ones only.

member.summary: Implements the incremental search functionality for the family of controls. Can be either consumed directly by the menu customizers to obtain the current search string, or used to produce a menu items filter to be included into the item filters stack in .

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.PopupMenu.Impl.SearchHost.InputString
member.summary: Gets or sets the string, as entered in the UI. The changes to this property are withheld for the grace period and after that they apply to the and properties. During that grace period, the is True, and will cause the changes to be applied immediately.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether the search is currently active. The setter fails silently if being set to False while is True.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether the search host cannot be deactivated.

member.summary: Gets whether there are pending changes to the

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.PopupMenu.Impl.SearchHost.IsValid
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the current is considered to be valid by the search-host consumer. If the search-host is used as a filter (), then this value reflects the number of items in the filter, meaning the search-string is valid iff there are items in the list after applying the filter. Otherwise, just the user-assigned value is stored.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.PopupMenu.Impl.SearchHost.SearchPredicate
member.summary: Gets the current filtering regex, based on the current . Func must return NaN to filter out the results. Otherwise it returns priority of item lexicographically (lower double means higher priority)

member.returns: NaN if no match. Priority otherwise.

summary.para: Creates the menu object and supplies it with environmental data.
There are two main usage scenarios:
• Add items to , sink events like or , and call or , or their overloads and variations.
• If the items are simple, call and then or , or their overloads and variations.

member.param: Required. The limiting lifetime of the menu. As you're passing in some components, your access to these components is limited by some lifetime (usually, the lifetime of the entity into which they were injected). To ensure safe access to these components, this lifetime must be passed to the menu.
Required. Common UI components.
Required. Governs whether popups are allowed to show.
Optional. Some functionality might be impaired if omitted.
Optional. Will not have a parent window if omitted.
Optional. Required for proper functioning of multilevel popup menus.
Optional. Required for proper interaction with other popup windows in the infrastructure.
Optional. Takes overrides from settings, otherwise uses settings' default values.

member.name: P:JetBrains.UI.PopupMenu.MenuItemDescriptor.Mnemonic
member.summary: If the menu is working in the mode, specifies the mnemonic to assign to this menu item. The letter holding the mnemonic will be underlined automatically. To specify a mnemonic, either: (1) set the to contain a plaintext copy of the item , with the mnemonic char prepended by an ampersand “&”; normal ampersands should be doubled in the text, or, (2) set the to contain the single case-insensitive character of the mnemonic, whose position in the will be determined automatically; it's also legal to specify a mnemonic not present in the text. May be Null.

member.summary: Whether the label should be shown with a checkbox which represents the : when the checkbox is checked, user can choose between the radio buttons and their values; otherwise, the radio buttons are disabled and the is assumed.

member.summary: Text of the label (of the checkbox if ).

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Controls.RadioGroupModel`1.NothingSelectedValue
member.summary: The when none of the radio buttons is selected. If , this is the when the checkbox gets unchecked and all the radio buttons get disabled.

summary.para: The composite value of this group.
Each radio button is assigned a value. When a radio button is selected, its value gets here. When this proprty changes, the corresponding radio button is also selected.

If , then the checkbox represents one more value, , which is in effect when the checkbox is not checked (and radio buttons are disabled). When the checkbox gets checked, one of the radio buttons gets selected and dictates its value.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.TreeGrid.TreeGridViewport.SetWin32Focus(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The SetFocus function sets the keyboard focus to the specified window. The window must be attached to the calling thread's message queue. The SetFocus function sends a WM_KILLFOCUS message to the window that loses the keyboard focus and a WM_SETFOCUS message to the window that receives the keyboard focus. It also activates either the window that receives the focus or the parent of the window that receives the focus. If a window is active but does not have the focus, any key pressed will produce the WM_SYSCHAR, WM_SYSKEYDOWN, or WM_SYSKEYUP message. If the VK_MENU key is also pressed, the lParam parameter of the message will have bit 30 set. Otherwise, the messages produced do not have this bit set. By using the AttachThreadInput function, a thread can attach its input processing to another thread. This allows a thread to call SetFocus to set the keyboard focus to a window attached to another thread's message queue.
member.param: [in] Handle to the window that will receive the keyboard input. If this parameter is NULL, keystrokes are ignored.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the handle to the window that previously had the keyboard focus. If the hWnd parameter is invalid or the window is not attached to the calling thread's message queue, the return value is NULL. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.TreeGrid.TreeGridViewport.GetWin32Focus
member.summary: The GetFocus function retrieves the handle to the window that has the keyboard focus, if the window is attached to the calling thread's message queue.
member.returns: The return value is the handle to the window with the keyboard focus. If the calling thread's message queue does not have an associated window with the keyboard focus, the return value is NULL.

summary.para: Manages the automation providers, as available for our custom controls.
Automation provider implementations require referencing the Avalon assemblies, which we cannot do yet.

When an Avalon-aware DLL is about to query for providers on our controls, it should load the providers DLL and cause them to sign up for this Registry. Subsequently, controls will start returning the providers in response to their .

member.remarks: The default implementation should call into System.Windows.Automation.Provider.AutomationInteropProvider::ReturnRawElementProvider.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.RenderGdipIntoAvalonImage(System.Windows.Size,JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.AlphaChannel,System.Action{System.Drawing.Graphics})
member.summary: Creates a GDI+ Graphics to render into, and returns the rendering result in a form of an Avalon image.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.RenderGdipIntoAvalonImage_GdiBitmap_DIBitmap(System.Windows.Size,JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.AlphaChannel,System.Action{System.Drawing.Graphics})
member.summary: Creates a GDI+ Graphics to render into, and returns the rendering result in a form of an Avalon image.
member.remarks: Thought it could re-use the bits of , but seems like it's not the way it works.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.RenderGdipIntoAvalonImage_GdipBitmap(System.Windows.Size,JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.AlphaChannel,System.Action{System.Drawing.Graphics})
member.summary: Creates a GDI+ Graphics to render into, and returns the rendering result in a form of an Avalon image.
member.remarks: Creates a byte buffer, a GDI+ bitmap right on these bytes, and then an Avalon image off these bytes. Could be easily turned into a to reuse its bytes on subsequent renders of the same size, but in this method if a GDI DC is created off the GDIP DC, then any transparency functions would fail (cannot get the back color it seems), like ClearType or even rectangles with alpha. So we cannot use it as a main method, and thus no use optimizing into a .

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.RenderGdipIntoAvalonImage_GdiBitmap_DIBSection(System.Windows.Size,JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.AlphaChannel,System.Action{System.Drawing.Graphics})
member.summary: Creates a GDI+ Graphics to render into, and returns the rendering result in a form of an Avalon image.
member.remarks: Creates a GDI bitmap, HDC on it, Graphics on that, and uses the GDI bitmap bytes to create an Avalon image off those. Not quite compatible with because the bits are created by anew each time.

member.summary: A data rule finder to traverse thru both worlds (Avalon & WinForms) crossing the boundaries successfully and gathering rules from the whole chain.
member.remarks: Required for correct operation on mixed content. E.g. at this moment (Fall'11) tool window frame is WinForms while it content is Avalon at times (e.g. Stack Trace Explorer), which causes data rules collection to stop within WPF and fail with collecting the CloseAll data rules on its WinForms parent.

member.summary: Arguments to the routed event.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Avalon.DataContext.GetDataRulesEventArgs.GetDataRulesEvent
member.summary: Fires when the a Data Context is about to be created and looks for s on Avalon UI elements to query for data. This event will fire when you call interface members on , or the method and its siblings. When you sink the event, add your data rules to the list. Do not set to True so that the event could bubble up and collect all of the data providers in the UI tree. Add your data rules to the end, which will make sure the deepest controls take precedence with their most concrete data (unless data rule priority is specifically overridden).

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Avalon.DataContext.GetDataRulesEventArgs.DataRules
member.summary: Add your data rules to the end of this collection. See documentation for details.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Avalon.DataContext.GetDataRulesEventArgs.GetDataRulesBehaviorProperty
member.summary: If you want a control to publish data rules, set this property on the view to the handler defined in the viewmodel, and it will be attached to sink the event.

summary.para: Base class for icon identifiers to icons whose images might have animation on screen.
Such icons should yield a reasonable image when queried through the regular static APIs.
The exact protocol for getting their animation storyboard or frames is not defined yet, and is specific to the particular type of icon IDs.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Icons.CompiledIcons.CompiledIconIdOwner.IconPack.ReadFromDictionary(System.Windows.ResourceDictionary,System.Object[])
member.summary: Reads the serialized format, as emitted by the build task.
member.param: If the exact set and order of the IDs is known, validates that the loaded set is the same.

remarks.para: On the format.
Each dictionary entry is a of some icon for some theme.
It has two attributes, attached property is the icon ID, and the attached property is the theme of this icon image.

The dictionary keys on entries have no meaning, but define the sorting order. In that order, images are sorted lexicographically, first by icon ID, then by theme. This way, you're guaranteed to read all images of the same icon in a row.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Icons.CompiledIcons.CompiledIconsPackAttribute
member.summary: An assembly-level attribute which is autogenerated by the Compiled Themed Icons support code. These are collected by (without loading assemblies/types) to discover the available icons, and actual icon images are loaded from BAML resources on demand.

summary.para: Normalized names of the icons in this pack. The ordering is an undefined behavior of the icon compiler.
Icon names are used for all generated accessor fields and classes for the icon.

Icon names must be unique thoughout the system, but pack+index pair is used for identifying/getting the icon internally. The reason is to enforce strong references to icons and prohibit the use of plaintext strings. That's why the icons order in this list is not stable.
Unique identifier of this icon pack; also, an URI to the BAML with icon images.
Each compiled icon is uniquelly identified by a pair of and an index of the icon in the list.

summary.para: Gets the icon GDI+ raster image for use in WinForms UI.
This image only fits the current theme. You should watch changes and request a new image, or use .
The icon is rasterized with device-independent 96dpi for this method. In screen UI, you should better use for higher-resolution icons.

remarks.para: If the icon with such an ID is not registered with the system, an exception is logged and a placeholder image of the standard 16x16 size is returned, and execution continues.

member.returns: The icon (of its natural size), or the standard 16x16 image if the icon is not registered.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Icons.ThemedIconManager.LiveImages
member.summary: Caches properties with live images (which follow theme changes). Purposes: (1) no explicit lifetiming or strong references so that this stuff could be addressed from WPF; (2) reuse of existing property instance. Maps: strong ref to icon id => weak ref to property. Properties should be gone when they're not needed anymore, but should be held while they're of any use. If icon IDs are transient monikers, they might get wasted before their icon goes off scope, or then recreated => should not drop the entry when IconID is not explicitly used if the property is still there. Properties are not bound explicitly to avoid strongreferences. Instead, they're all bulk-updated when theme changes.

remarks.para: We need that hack to avoid exceptions when System.Windows.Forms.Application tries to cast our managed component to the type System.Windows.Forms.UnsafeNativeMethods.IMsoComponent. This cast fails for managed IMsoComponent but works fine for native COM IMsoComponent objects.

After that, you can call one of the Write methods.

summary.para: If async reading from the source fails, the error message is assigned here on the UI thread. This means that the model is async-ready, but won't be able to proceed.
Either or will be assigned on the UI thread when the async reading is completed.
Whenif async reading from the source succeeds, the description on the read data is assigned here (to the root items list of the tree model) on the UI thread.

summary.para: Import this type into options page ctor to get the Settings Store context for saving your Options Page settings.
Use this for binding your Options Page settings controls in real time.

In case you need to manually control the context your settings go to (like when they reference solution information and thus have no meaning in the global context), take and operate it directly. In default cases, use this context (which is a context in the same Settings Store).

This context belongs to a Settings Store transaction, so you can freely modify it in Options UI and access this data across pages. The choice of the context depends on the user's settings editing mode: either Smart Save by default, or writing to a specific storage in Advanced mode.
This is the context in which you should be modifying settings while editing the options.
It is exposed with delegating members of this class.
This is the baseline context which reflects the settings as they were when Options dialog was just opened (or after the Reset/Apply button).
Never write to this context. Use it to detect changes made to specific settings.
Import this type into options page ctor to get the Settings Store in the transaction context of the Options Dialog.
Use this ONLY if you need non-default settings context behavior (e.g. are always working per-solution).
By default, is the correct choice for most of the settings.

You can apply all of your settings changes immediately from the UI. This Settings Store belongs to a separate transaction and will not affect the application until the Options Dialog is committed with OK button.
If you import into your page view class constructor, you will get this same transactioned store instead of the global one.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Avalon.AvalonEx.MakeGeometryBrush(System.Windows.Media.Geometry,System.Windows.Media.SolidColorBrush,System.Windows.Media.Pen)
member.summary: For a geometry, creates a brush that could be used to paint a rectangle with a geometry. The geometry spans the whole brush area. The coordinate space of the geometry is assumed to be (0,0)-(1000,1000). It would have been better to have (0,0)-(1,1), but some of the Avalon geometry clippers revert to rough edges on sizes less than one.
member.param: The Geometry.
Brush. Optional.
Pen (brush + thinkness). Optional.
member.returns: The brush that paints the geometry.

summary.para: Creates a lifetime each time the control gets loaded into the tree of loaded elements.
This emulates a deterministic lifetime for WPF elements.
This overload does not take an outer lifetime and is suitable for use in purely-view controls that do not know any external lifetime.
Note that it's not technically guaranteed that the lifetime is ever terminated.
Creates a lifetime each time the control gets loaded into the tree of loaded elements.
This emulates a deterministic lifetime for WPF elements.

member.summary: Rasterizes a vector image into a raster image of the standard DPI.
member.param: The vector drawing to be rendered.
DPI resolution to use when rasterizing.

Optional expected raster size, in device-independent pixels. If Null, the image will be rendered in its natural size. Otherwise, it will be rescaled (in vector, if possible). Uniform scaling is not enforced.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Avalon.AvalonEx.Rasterize(System.Windows.Media.ImageSource,JetBrains.Util.Interop.DpiResolution,System.Nullable{System.Windows.Size})
member.summary: Rasterizes a vector image into a raster image of the standard DPI. Checks if the image is already a raster or if it's a and could be used instead. Otherwise, renders the image the common way.
member.param: The image to ensure rasterization. If this is already a raster, it will be returned AS IS (unless it has to be resized). Beware writable bitmaps.
DPI resolution to use when rasterizing.

Optional expected raster size, in device-independent pixels. If Null, the image will be rendered in its natural size. Otherwise, it will be rescaled (in vector, if possible). Uniform scaling is not enforced.

member.summary: Sets the value of the property to point to a WPF Dynamic Resource, just like {DynamicResource resourcekey} in XAML.
member.remarks: Theoretically, the resource key could also be a string or just any object, but too free a constraint makes compile-time validation worse (and at runtime it just silently skips), so let's limit to .

summary.para: Creates a new instance of a UI control representing the given Automation Object.
The must be reachable, and a view must be registered for this to work.

Note that you should NOT use this method where content object is expected (like in 's property, or any items). Pass the automation object directly instead, because this method uses the same technique for presenting the content as they would.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.CreateOrReuseWindow
member.summary: Allows to show popup UI when the user clicks a button. Shows the old window if not closed yet, or creates a new one if not shown yet or already closed.
member.remarks: Usually, in Avalon, the window would be created initially, and show-hidden on user actions without actually destroying and recreating it. In our case there're usually complex bindings running in the window, so we would not like them to be running in the hidden mode.

Owner window.

member.summary: Converts source values to a value for the binding target. The data binding engine calls this method when it propagates the values from source bindings to the binding target.
member.returns: A converted value.If the method returns null, the valid null value is used.A return value of . indicates that the converter did not produce a value, and that the binding will use the if it is available, or else will use the default value.A return value of . indicates that the binding does not transfer the value or use the or the default value.
member.param: The array of values that the source bindings in the produces. The value indicates that the source binding has no value to provide for conversion.
The type of the binding target property.
The converter parameter to use.
The culture to use in the converter.

member.summary: Converts a binding target value to the source binding values.
member.returns: An array of values that have been converted from the target value back to the source values.
member.param: The value that the binding target produces.
The array of types to convert to. The array length indicates the number and types of values that are suggested for the method to return.
The converter parameter to use.
The culture to use in the converter.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Application.WindowUtil.SetOwnerReliable(System.Windows.Forms.Form,System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window)
member.summary: Sets an owner for the form in a reliable manner. The problem with reliability is that if the owner is not another (ie cannot be used), and form-to-be-owned is not , then the netfx implementation will drop the owner assigned with WinAPI calls and replace it with its own parking window (kinda to prevent it from showing up in the taskbar). This is done after the handle is created and after all of the notifications, so we should wait some more and then reapply the desired parent.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Application.WindowUtil.ShowFocusCatcher(System.Void*)
member.summary: Shows a window that catches focus and then returns it back immediately, so that the window could process the activation message consistently and place focus on the proper child window. Without that it could happen that focus sits directly on the main window and no child is active.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Application.WindowUtil.ShowDialogWithGuardedCreation(JetBrains.DataFlow.Lifetime,JetBrains.UI.Application.WindowUtil.Modality,System.Func{JetBrains.DataFlow.LifetimeDefinition,JetBrains.DataFlow.Lifetime,System.Windows.Window},JetBrains.Threading.IThreading,System.Object)

summary.para: Shows the dialog either modally or nonmodally, so that its creation function were guarded, but its execution were not wholy guarded.
Guarding the creation is needed to process modal functions correctly.

Non-guarding the body of execution is required for controls which would be queueing smth guarded to function correctly: if the dialog is guarded throughout its whole lifetime, their activities would not have a chance to execute before it's closed.
If you're calling this method for modal execution, the obviously must not be held at the moment, otherwise it's not possible to fulfil the conditions.

member.param: Limiting lifetime for the whole activity.
Whether to show modally or non-modally.
Dialog creation function.
instance.
Optional. Owner window — either a WPF object, or an implementation over a Win32 HWND or WinForms window, or NULL to let WPF decide for choosing an owner on its own.
member.returns: If executing modally, the execution result. Otherwise, NULL.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Application.WindowUtil.ShowDialogModality
member.summary: Context parameter for Show Options action: whether to show dialog modally or not.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Application.WindowUtil.Modality
member.summary: Whether to show a dialog modally or nonmodally.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Application.WindowUtil.Modality.Nonmodal
member.summary: The dialog is shown nonmodally. Its creation function might be executed offstack if that is required to open a transaction.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Application.WindowUtil.Modality.Modal
member.summary: The dialog is executed modally, but not necessarily on the same stack: the execution function might return before the dialog is actually shown, in case that is required to open a transaction.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Application.WindowUtil.Modality.ModalThisStack
member.summary: The dialog is executed modally exactly on this stack, so that the execution function returns only after the dialog is completed. This requires that is not held at call time (otherwise the transaction cannot be opened in the given invariants).

summary.para: Gets the Settings Store context for saving your Options Page settings.
Use this for binding your Options Page settings controls in real time.

In case you need to manually control the context your settings go to (like when they reference solution information and thus have no meaning in the global context), take and operate it directly. In default cases, use this context (which is a context in the same Settings Store).

This context belongs to a Settings Store transaction, so you can freely modify it in Options UI and access this data across pages. The choice of the context depends on the user's settings editing mode: either Smart Save by default, or writing to a specific storage in Advanced mode.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Options.Defaultness.AllInDefault
member.summary: All of the controlled settings are not defined in this context and have their default values.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Options.Defaultness.SomeSetExplicitlyToDefaultValue
member.summary: All of the controlled settings are in their default values, but at least some has been set to these explicitly (instead of being undefined and falling back to defaults).

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Options.Defaultness.SomeSetToNonDefault
member.summary: At least some of the control settings are assigned nondefault values in this context.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Options.Dirtiness.AllClean
member.summary: None of the settings in this context have been changed as compared to the clean transaction.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Options.Dirtiness.SomeDirty
member.summary: Some of the settings in this context have been edited within this options transaction.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Options.OptionsManager
member.summary: Manages the Options Dialog subsystem. Must not have its own nontrivial logic, is just a façade for the subsystem's components. Within the subsystem, use individual components; outside the subsystem, import this component to avoid going into the implementation details.
member.remarks: An option page has three levels of existence: • ID, a unique string identifier. • Descriptor, an instance of the class. Created when adding pages to the manager. Lives until removed. • View, a WinForms control created from the Descriptor, lives only for the run of the Options dialog.

summary.para: Lists the known option pages.
When the option pages tree needs to be built, these are organized into a one-time tree of s.
Generally, they're collected from the classes implementing and marked with . You can promote your own page entities with as needed.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Options.OptionsManager.AddOptionsPage(JetBrains.DataFlow.Lifetime,System.Type,JetBrains.UI.Options.OptionsPageAttribute)
member.summary: Manually registers a page for the Options dialog (in addition to pages regularly discovered from ).
member.param: Duration.
Type of the page class implementing the interface.
Attribute with page metadata.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Options.OptionsManager.CreateOptionPagesTree
member.summary: When option pages tree needs to be presented, builds the tree structure. A new one is built each time so that to account for possible option pages dynamic additions/removals by plugins and user code. Page parent references are validated for existence and cycles when building the tree.

Presentable name of this page (to be shown in the tree of pages)
Icon ID of image for this page. If null, default image is used.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Options.OptionsPageAttribute.CompareTo(JetBrains.UI.Options.OptionsPageAttribute)
member.summary: Compares the current object with another object of the same type.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer that indicates the relative order of the objects being compared. The return value has the following meanings: Value Meaning Less than zero This object is less than the other parameter.Zero This object is equal to other. Greater than zero This object is greater than other.
member.param: An object to compare with this object.

Flags that identify when to destroy the form.

The task to run. The given to the task is always free-threaded for both reading and writing, even if .

Allows the owner to attach its UI to the progress of the task. The object given as parameter is always primary-threaded, which means that it fires modifications on the primary thread only. To cancel out the UI or binding, submit to the parameter. Optionally return the window handle, if known already, to keep from disabling when applying the modal state.
The owner-provided progress indicator.
The window focus will be restored to if it was impossible to restore focus to the previous window.

summary.para: A simple implementation of a text tool tip on the status bar indicator in the whole.
This is only triggered if the 's view does not handle tooltip on itself, in either WPF or Windowless Control.

Handling of the tooltip on the view might be required if you want to have different tooltips over different indicator areas, or present advanced tooltip content. Handling the tooltip with this method is simpler and also applies advanced layouting for the tooltip so that it didn't cover the indicator.

member.summary: Call this method if you would like to show the menu. Your code will be called to fill the menu with items and define their behavior after the menu is initialized and before it's shown. The lifetime will be terminated when the menu closes (limited by the indicator lifetime).

summary.para: Does subclassing of the standard WinAPI Status Bar control to attach it to the application's .
Suitable for Visual Studio 7–9 and WinForms standalone applications like DT.

This only implements insering the indicators. Text and emphasis must be handled elsewhere (the reason is that e.g. in VS text is handled with std api while indicators have to be hacked in with subclassing).

summary.para: Represents the frame that sites active controls, for example, the text control. This frame knows whether it's visible on screen, and sometimes it can cause the environment to switch so that the frame became visible.
In Visual Studio, an example of such frames is an editor tab or a tool window, in which case this implementation is based on the VS Window Frame interface.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.WindowManagement.WindowFrame.#ctor(JetBrains.Threading.IThreading)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.WindowManagement.WindowFrame.Bag
member.summary: Allows to attach payload. For instance, the raw VS Window Frame lives here.

summary.para: Notifies the hosted control that the frame has been closed and the content is illegitimate from now on.
Not guaranteed to fire.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.WindowManagement.WindowFrame.Disposables
member.summary: Lifetime control.

summary.para: Gets whether the frame is currently visible onscreen, which tries to take into account not only the visibility flag of the window, but also whether the window layout allows content control to be visible onscreen.
This property is guarded, which means that all of the property changes will only occur in the guarded context.
Gets the root parent HWND for this window frame. This window should be used as owner for window popups over the frame content.

The root parent window is the window that has no parent (see ) and whose descendant “contains” this frame. For HWND-based UI, it's the top-level window containing the HWND of the frame. For Avalon UI, it's the top-level window containing the HWND presentation source of the UI element (or Null, if the element is not parented by a HWND presentation source).

Could be Null if the frame is not hosted on an HWND or the frame implementation cannot provide this value. Could change if the frame is reparented into another top-level window (eg floating a VS10 text view element).

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.WindowManagement.WindowFrame.SwitchToFrameRequested
member.summary: Tries to make True. Even if successful, might not apply immediately, as the changes to the occur in the reentrancy-guarded context only.

summary.para: Gets the UI element that represents the window frame, in either UI framework, if exposed by the window frame.
For HWND-based UI, query this object for the interface. For Avalon UI, try casting to 2D or 3D Avalon elements.

summary.para: Exposes the central Resource Dictionary whch should be available to every piece of WPF UI within the platform-based product.
Some of the UI controls rely on theming colors, icons, automation object views and other resources which must be externally applied to them thru this dictionary.
If you would like to publish a resource to make it universally available:
(1) Look for an existing subsystem for registering your kind of resources, such as an icon or a color. Thus subsystem will expose them for you through this dictionary.
(2) If this is a new kind of resources, add a new to the collection of .

If you're authoring a new top-level WPF control (Window, Visual Studio Tool Window integration, etc), make sure to publish this dictionary on your WPF controls tree root. See for an MVVM helper for that.
Exposes the central Resource Dictionary whch should be available to every piece of WPF UI within the platform-based product.
Some of the UI controls rely on theming colors, icons, automation object views and other resources which must be externally applied to them thru this dictionary.
If you would like to publish a resource to make it universally available:
(1) Look for an existing subsystem for registering your kind of resources, such as an icon or a color. Thus subsystem will expose them for you through this dictionary.
(2) If this is a new kind of resources, add a new to the collection of .

If you're authoring a new top-level WPF control (Window, Visual Studio Tool Window integration, etc), make sure to publish this dictionary on your WPF controls tree root. See for an MVVM helper for that.
